Credits.Story By: DEE DEE MYERS & LAWRENCE O'DONNELL JR.

Scenes.Scene Heading: CUT TO: INT. THE WHITE HOUSE - LEO'S OFFICE - NIGHT
Scenes.Description: Sam walks inside the office, where C.J. is waiting.

Dialogues.Line: What happened?
It's not as bad as you think, C.J.
Was the President's nominee for the Supreme Court just arrested for drunk driving?
Yes.
Then it's pretty bad, isn't it?
Sure.
I thought he doesn't drink.
He doesn't drink.
He was tonight.
C.J., we've vetted the man. I'm not saying he's not a heavy drinker, I'm saying he doesn't drink.
Then what was he pulled over for?
Driving while being...Hispanic.
Does Toby know?
[enters] I stepped off the edge of the world.
[to C.J.] Yes.
Where'd this happen?
Wesley, Connecticut.
Why'd he refuse the Breathalyzer?
'Cause he's a crazy man who's out to ruin my life.
Toby?
That's what he's out to do. Has anyone posted bail?
No.
Why not?
They can't find a judge.
Why not?
It's not Cook County, Toby. It's Friday night in Wesley, Connecticut.
Believe me when I tell you this, C.J. I will figure out a way to blame this on you.
I have no doubt about that. LEO walks in.

Have someone find his lawyer and talk to him. Sam, there's an Air Force Lear jet with its motor running. Fly to Westchester County airport, rent a car, drive to Wesley, and get the next associate Justice of the Supreme Court out of jail. C.J., Sam sees one reporter when he gets off that plane, I'm gonna blame you.
Toby's got you covered there. Sam and C.J. start to leave.
I'm going with Sam.
Toby.
The judge and I are gonna have an abrupt conversation.
I want my phone to ring once every 15 minutes. I want to know what's going on! Toby, Sam and C.J. leave the office.

Scenes.Scene Heading: SMASH CUT TO: MAIN TITLES.
FADE IN: INT. LECTURE HALL - NIGHT
Scenes.Description: The lecture series continues.

Dialogues.Line: Josh, why don't you start by telling us about a typical day at the White House?
Well, the first thing I'll tell you is, there's no such thing. [audience laughs]
There's a schedule and there's a structure to be sure, and to a certain extent it starts out as a 9-to-5 job, but you can pretty much count on it being blown to hell by 9:30. [audience laughs]
Give us an example.

I-I'll give you an example from this week. In fact, the story I'm about to tell you all happened within the last 36 hours. Anyone who's been reading the papers in the last few days has probably been following along with what we call the news cycle that wouldn't end. Depending on how you look at it, it started either with a cabinet secretary losing her temper, a committee chairman baiting her during a hearing, the President answering a question he shouldn't have, a dentist appointment, or me being stupid. [audience laughs] For the record, I'd like to say that I don't think it was as much my fault as other people do. [audience laughs] One thing's for sure, it started out as a day that was supposed to trumpet the President's vision for educational reform.

Scenes.Scene Heading: CUT TO: INT. PRESS BRIEFING ROOM - PREVIOUS MORNING
Scenes.Description: Sam, Toby, and C.J. are in the empty press briefing room, going over the next briefing.

Dialogues.Line: Give me the bullet points.
I understand this stuff.
Excellent.
I really do.
I have complete confidence in you.
Thank you.
Give him the bullet points.
I feel bathed in your confidence as well, Toby.
C.J.?
Forgive student loans to people who become teachers --
And?

-- and spend at least three years teaching in a rural or inner-city school. Give cash bonuses to people who leave other careers to become teachers and provide federal money for grants to individual school districts to use older, more experienced teachers to train younger, less experienced teachers.
Should note that half of all new teachers quit in the first three years.
It's right here on my index card, Toby. [shows him index card]
Very good, then.
[comes in the door] Toby.
Yeah.
Got a minute?
Yeah. Josh and Toby head out one door, as C.J. and Sam get ready to leave by the other.
Thank you both.
Hey, you know what?
What?
What time is your briefing?
Eleven o'clock.
We should push it to one o'clock. Sam and C.J. leave the briefing room into the HALLWAY. Carol follows them behind.
I thought about that.
Do it after the bill signing. Let this be the story. Let's control the news cycle.
Carol, let's move the briefing to one.
You can't.
Why not?
You have the thing.
Yes, and this is a perfect excuse to postpone the thing.
You really don't wanna do that.
You have a thing?
I have a dentist appointment at noon.
What's wrong?
Nothing's wrong.
C.J.?
I'm experiencing some pain.
For how long?
About a month now, but it'll go away by itself.
When?
When I die, Sam. [to Carol] Carol, cancel the appointment. [walks into her office]
Carol, set the briefing for two o'clock. Keep the appointment.
Sam! They enter C.J.'S OFFICE.
Your teeth are the best friends you got, C.J.
They are?
You take care of them, they'll take care of you.
When'd you start talking like this?
I'm nuts for dental hygiene.
Go away. Now.
Okay. [leaves]

Scenes.Scene Heading: CUT TO: INT. HALLWAY - CONTINUOUS
Scenes.Description: Josh and Toby head for the Communications Office. Josh has just told Toby some news.

Dialogues.Line: She called him a racist?
She didn't use that word.
What word did she use?
Well, yes, she used that word. Toby and Josh walk in the COMMUNICATIONS OFFICE.
Bonnie. Ginger.
Yes?
I want anything that might be on the wire already about the HUD Secretary calling Jack Wooden a racist.
You want it now?
No, Bonnie, I want it at whatever leisurely pace you two feel...
I'm just asking.
I want it now. [to Josh] On C-SPAN, she called him a racist?
Nah, not just Wooden. She was pretty careful to include all Republicans. [chuckles]
Why are you good humored about this?
She was baited.
Don't care.
She was baited and she was right.
Good for her.
[walks in, carrying a sheet of paper] Excuse me, Josh. Did you know that Deborah O'Leary called...?
Is that a wire story?
What's it say?

[reads from paper] 'Wooden's lengthy recitation of problems confronting public housing drew an angry response from Secretary O'Leary.' Here's what she said: ''Public housing has serious problems, Mr. Chairman, I don't deny that. But if you and your colleagues in the Republican party...''
[groans] No!

[continues reading] ''...were as invested in solving the problems associated with poverty as you are in scoring political points on the backs of poor people and minorities, you might just see the value.' 'Are you calling me a racist?' Wooden shot back.'
'Of course not,' she answered wisely?
[reading] ''If the shoe fits,' responded the secretary.'
Well, wasn't that clever of her? [goes in his office]

Scenes.Scene Heading: CUT TO: INT. LECTURE HALL - PRESENT

Dialogues.Line: Donald Morales, who is the spokesman for the Department of Housing and Urban Development, and who was wishing he hadn't gotten out of bed that morning, confirms what happened. Now there's the matter of telling the President.

Scenes.Scene Heading: CUT TO: INT. THE OVAL OFFICE - PREVIOUS MORNING
Scenes.Description: Bartlet is just reading the story. Toby, Josh, Sam and Leo are with him.

Dialogues.Line: 'If the shoe fits!'
Gets a little bit worse, actually.
[reading] 'When reporters confronted Secretary O'Leary in a hallway outside the hearing room, she defended...' Oh come on!
Don't worry about it.
Leo!
I'll take care of it. [to staff] She on her way here?
She'll be here in half an hour.
[knocks and comes in] Mr. President?
Yeah. [to staff] Let's go. [They all head out of the Oval Office.] 'If the shoe fits.' Is that the best she could do?
Of her many transgressions, Mr. President, let's not worry about she resorted to clichE. They all walk in THE MURAL ROOM, which is full of reporters.
Ladies and gentlemen, the President of the United States.

Scenes.Scene Heading: CUT TO: INT. LECTURE HALL - PRESENT
Scenes.Description: Josh continues to talk.

Dialogues.Line: The President spoke briefly. [pause] The President has never spoken briefly in his life! [audience laughs] But, he spoke. He signed the bill. He gave away the pens. Then he took a few questions from the press. Now, before I go on, it should be pointed out that according to every poll conducted in the universe, the issue that concerns Americans more than any other is education. Now, The President has just signed off on $700,000,000 in new money for education and announced a plan of aggressive education initiative. What do you suppose the first question from the press was?

Scenes.Scene Heading: CUT TO: INT. THE MURAL ROOM - PREVIOUS MORNING

Dialogues.Line: Mr. President, do you agree with Secretary O'Leary that Congressman Wooden is a racist, and if not, do you plan on asking for her resignation? The President is sitting at a desk in the Mural Room, with Toby, Sam, Josh and Leo standing beside him. Danny is part of the group of reporters surrounding them. Cameras flash everywhere.

Let me say that I have great confidence in Deborah O'Leary. She's done a terrific job at HUD, helping thousands of people make the very difficult transition from joblessness and homelessness to more fulfilling and productive lives. Other reporters start to ask questions, but Danny cuts them off.
I'm sorry, Mr. President. You didn't answer the question.
I was hoping you weren't going to notice that, Danny.
I did, sir.

Then I will tell you that I agree the Republican Party does not have a comprehensive program for combating poverty in this country. That being said, there are countless Republicans who are working very hard to change their party's legacy on some of these issues. And I hope to be working with them to do just that. Reporters start asking questions again, but Danny takes over once again.
I'm sure that was an answer to some question, Mr. President. It just wasn't the answer to mine.

Scenes.Scene Heading: CUT TO: INT. LECTURE HALL - PRESENT

Dialogues.Line: If only we'd stopped it right there. If only we'd said, uh, 'Sorry, The President can't take any questions right now,' or, uh, 'We'll cover this in a briefing,' or, 'The building is on fire!' [audience laughs] But for some reason, it took us all a moment to realize that there was no Press Secretary in the room.

Scenes.Scene Heading: CUT TO: INT. THE MURAL ROOM - PREVIOUS MORNING
Scenes.Description: Bartlet continues to answer Danny's question.

Dialogues.Line: Frankly, I think she went too far in assigning motive to Congressman Wooden and the Republican Party.
Will you be speaking to her?
She'll be meeting with Leo McGarry.
Will he ask her to apologize?
An apology'd be appropriate. Leo and Josh have just realized what Bartlet just said.
Oh, get him off.
[fakes cough] Sam!
[steps forward and addresses the room] Folks, all this is gonna be covered in the two o'clock briefing. The President's late for lunch with the U.N. ambassador. I'm sorry.
[to reporters] Thank you everyone. [gets up and they head back towards the Oval Office] That went pretty well.
We'll fix it.
Sam.
Yeah?
The U.N. ambassador is in Portugal.
Okay. My bad.

Scenes.Scene Heading: CUT TO: INT. LECTURE HALL - PRESENT

Dialogues.Line: Eight words. 'The President's not taking any questions right now.' If we'd just stepped in 30 seconds sooner. Josh's cellphone rings.

That's me. I'm sorry. I, uh-there's a thing. I have... I have to answer this now. This'll just, uh, take a second. This is weird, I know, but, uh, anyway... Josh takes off his mike, goes BACKSTAGE, and answers his phone.
Yeah.
Yeah, it's me.
Are you there yet?

Scenes.Scene Heading: CUT TO: EXT. CONNECTICUT HIGHWAY - NIGHT
Scenes.Description: Sam is driving a car, and Toby is in the passenger seat.

Dialogues.Line: We're lost.
You're lost?
We're not lost.
You're from Connecticut. What exit do we want for Wesley?
What?
We missed the exit.
We didn't miss the exit.
Toby, I'm kind of in the middle of something here.
Just tell me.
You bet buddy.

Scenes.Scene Heading: CUT TO: INT. LECTURE HALL - CONTINUOUS

Dialogues.Line: Call me when you know something. [closes his phone and gets back to his seat] Sorry about that.
Can you tell us what that was about?
The, uh, trade deficit. Where was I?
If you'd only gotten there 30 seconds sooner.

The day would've gone a lot differently. The President had said that Secretary O'Leary should apologize. The press wanted to know if she would be fired if she didn't and we didn't have an answer. She was coming up to the White House for a showdown. This was what the day was about now. And the day was about to get worse...because I was about to step to the plate.

Scenes.Scene Heading: FADE IN: EXT. CONNECTICUT HIGHWAY - NIGHT
Scenes.Description: Toby and Sam are still in the car.

Dialogues.Line: We're going the wrong way.
No, we're not.
We're supposed to be going east.
We're going east.
How do you know we're going east?
The sun rises in the east.
It's dark outside!
Also, that bright star in the northern sky is Polaris.
So what?
I'm using celestial navigation.
Hey, Galileo, get off at the next exit and turn the car around.

Scenes.Scene Heading: CUT TO: INT. LECTURE HALL - NIGHT
Scenes.Description: Josh continues to tell his story.

Dialogues.Line: Secretary O'Leary was told that Leo McGarry wanted to see her as soon as possible. There was no question that she was going to be angry about the President publicly asking her to apologize, but at the moment, that was Leo's problem.

Scenes.Scene Heading: CUT TO: INT. LEO'S OFFICE - PREVIOUS AFTERNOON
Scenes.Description: Leo is talking to the Housing and Urban Development secretary, DEBORAH O'LEARY. O'LEARY I can't believe he did that, Leo.

Dialogues.Line: Debbie. O'LEARY How could he?
You're pissed at us? O'LEARY How could he publicly demand that I apologize without hearing my side of the story first?
We blew the press today, we'll come to that. But Debbie, I've got videotape of your side of the story. O'LEARY The man's a racist.
Maybe so... O'LEARY Maybe!
Debbie. O'LEARY He's using his government authority to spit at poor people and minorities, which in his mind are the same thing.
Look... O'LEARY He's doing it because he can. He's doing it because he can score points with his narrow-minded constituents.
His narrow-minded constituents are also our narrow-minded constituents. O'LEARY Oh, for crying out loud, Leo. [yells] When are you guys gonna stop running for President?

When angels dance on pinheads, Debbie. We need their votes on any number of issues, including, by the way, the budget for the department of Housing and Urban Development. O'LEARY Attacking HUD is code for attacking blacks.
[dryly] Thanks. Having been born yesterday on a turnip truck... O'LEARY Do you not think it is my role as the highest-ranking African-American woman in government to point out that...?
I think, Debbie, your role first and foremost is to serve the President--a task today at which you failed spectacularly. O'LEARY Leo...
You're gonna apologize. O'LEARY [thinks for a moment] I'm sorry.
Not to me, Debbie. O'LEARY Look, I called it like I saw it.
Well, now you're gonna apologize for it. O'LEARY I can't.
You can. O'LEARY I won't.
[forcefully] You will. O'LEARY Is that an order?

You're doing great work, Deb. The President's nuts about you, always has been. He'll cry for three minutes after he fires your ass and then he'll say 'What's next?' O'LEARY Leo, if I've gotta go and ask Wooden for forgiveness, he's gonna lord it over me from now until the end of time.
It's the cost of doing business. O'LEARY [gives in] Done.
Deb, he's been trying to provoke you for months. When you give in to him, you surrender the high ground. O'LEARY How did it happen?
You forgot what your grandfather taught you. O'LEARY What was that?
'Never argue with a drunk or a fool.' O'LEARY Is the President very angry with me?
Mostly he's upset that you couldn't come up with anything better than 'if the shoe fits.' [both chuckle] Good luck. O'LEARY Thank you. [leaves]

Scenes.Scene Heading: CUT TO: INT. LECTURE HALL - PRESENT

Dialogues.Line: So that should've been it, right? C.J. Cregg does the two o'clock briefing, tells them Secretary O'Leary has an apology for Congressman Wooden. All questions on the matter will be handled by her spokesperson, Donald Morales, and redirects their attention to the 700 million bucks of yours that we just spent on teachers. [pause] Who here has had emergency root canal?

Scenes.Scene Heading: CUT TO: INT. JOSH'S OFFICE - PREVIOUS AFTERNOON
Scenes.Description: C.J. knocks at the door. She has a swollen cheek and is speaking out of the side of her mouth.

Dialogues.Line: Yeah.
[muffled] Josh.
What the hell happened?
I had woot canaw.
What happened to your cheeks?
I had woot canaw.
Why are you talking like that?
[louder] I had woot canaw!
Yeah, I heard you the first time, I was just amusing myself.
I can suggest some othew things you can do wiff yourseff.
Are you in pain?
[shouts] I had woot canaw! [grabs her jaw with a pained expression]
You're gonna need to stop saying that, 'cause you just look and sound so ridiculous. [walks out into the bullpen with C.J. following him]
I have to cancew the bwiefing.
You can't cancel the briefing.
Wook at me.
You'll be great.
I can't do the bwiefing.
Why not?
I can't even say 'bwiefing.'
You can't cancel the briefing, C.J. You got to wrap up O'Leary, you got to move them back to the bill signing.
Yoshua!
Sorry, did... did you just say my name?
You weally think I can do it?
Don't be insane, C.J. You're not going to a press briefing looking like Bullwinkle.
Oh, so once again you'we just hawing a wittle fun!
Yeah.
Ha ha ha ha ha. They head back into JOSH's OFFICE.
When can you take the cotton out?
Two houws. I'w have Cawow cancew the bwiefing.
No, we're still doing it.
Who?
Me.
No way!
C.J.?
You get howstiwe.
I get... hot stuff?
Howstiwe. Howstiwe. You get howstiwe!
I don't get hostile! I don't get randomly hostile, I get hostile when hostility's called for.
Wet Sam do it.
Sam went to Foggy Bottom.
What's he doing in Fwoggy Bowtew?
[laughs] I just wanted to see if I could make you say 'Foggy Bottom.' Sam's working with the speechwriters.
Toby?
Toby's with Leo and the President.
Josh...
[pulls on suit jacket and heads out] Hey there cats and kittens. This is Josh Lyman coming at you with your two o'clock briefing!
Josh, pwease be vewy cawefuw. Twy vewy, vewy hawd not to destwoy us.
You shouldn't say that C.J., you've got a great body... Here we go. Woo!

Scenes.Scene Heading: CUT TO: INT. THE BRIEFING ROOM - PREVIOUS AFTERNOON
Scenes.Description: Carol is speaking into the P.A. system. Josh comes in and is stopped by Danny.

Dialogues.Line: Please take your seats, we'll start the briefing. Please take your seats.
Josh.
Hey, Danny.
You're not gonna do this.
Do the briefing?
You're not gonna do this.
I talk to reporters all the time.
You really don't want to do this.

Let me tell you something, mi compadre. You guys have been coddled. I'm not your girlfriend, I'm not your camp counselor, and I'm not you sixth grade teacher you had a crush on. I'm a graduate of Harvard and Yale and I believe that my powers of debate can rise to meet the Socratic wonder that is the White House Press Corps. [heads to the podium]
Okey-dokey.

Scenes.Scene Heading: CUT TO: INT. C.J.'S OFFICE - PREVIOUS AFTERNOON
Scenes.Description: C.J. is watching the briefing on the T.V.

Dialogues.Line: Good afternoon, everybody. Would you take your seats. Uh, C.J. has a dental emergency, so I'll handle the briefing today.

Scenes.Scene Heading: CUT TO: INT. LECTURE HALL - PRESENT

Dialogues.Line: I'd like to say a couple things in my own defense. First of all, everything was fine. I dispensed of the Deborah O'Leary matter with ease and poise. I opened the room up to questions while imposing a discipline I felt had been lacking in C.J.'s briefings.

Scenes.Scene Heading: CUT TO: INT. BRIEFING ROOM - PREVIOUS AFTERNOON
Scenes.Description: Josh is at the podium doing the briefing.

Dialogues.Line: I'm gonna take one question a piece.
Josh!
Mike.
When was the last time the President has a cigarette?
Mike, you sure you want your one question to be that stupid?

Scenes.Scene Heading: CUT TO: INT. C.J.'S OFFICE - CONTINUOUS
Scenes.Description: C.J. is still watching the briefing. A reporter, Katie, remarks on Josh's response.

Dialogues.Line: It's not a stupid question, Josh.
Oh my God.
If the President's going to continue to be so adamantly anti-tobacco, why is it unreasonable to ask if he's a smoker?

Scenes.Scene Heading: CUT TO: INT. BRIEFING ROOM - CONTINUOUS

Dialogues.Line: The President quit smoking years ago.
He bummed a cigarette from me on Air Force One two days ago.

Scenes.Scene Heading: CUT TO: INT. C.J.'S OFFICE - CONTINUOUS

Dialogues.Line: Oh my God.

Scenes.Scene Heading: CUT TO: INT. BRIEFING ROOM - CONTINUOUS

Dialogues.Line: Well, then, uh... Jonathan.
So, you're not gonna answer Katie's question?
I'll look into it. Danny?

Josh, your comments were that the continuing drop in unemployment will create increased pressure on wages. In effect, driving them up. Is the President worried that this could lead to a resurgence of inflation?
Let me emphasize the President is pleased that unemployment has dropped another point five percent as a result...
I'm sure we all join the President in his joy, but I'm wondering if the President has a plan to fight the resulting inflation.
The President will do everything in his power to maintain the robust economy that has created millions of new jobs, improved productivity and kept a lid on inflation.
But he has no plan to address inflation specifically?
Twenty-four PhD's and a Counsel of Economy Advisors, Katie. They have a plan to fight inflation.
Is the reason you won't tell us about it that it's a secret?
[sarcastic] Yeah, Danny. We have a secret inflation plan.

Scenes.Scene Heading: CUT TO: INT. C.J.'S OFFICE - CONTINUOUS

Dialogues.Line: [now cringing] Oh my God!

Scenes.Scene Heading: CUT TO: INT. LECTURE HALL - PRESENT

Dialogues.Line: I guess that's pretty much when the wheels came off the wagon.

Josh, right here is a good time to take our break. Everybody, let's stretch our legs for five minutes. Sign-up sheets for 202 are in the lobby. If you smoke, apparently you can bum a cigarette on Air Force One. Let's have a hand for our guest Joshua Lyman. The audience applauds.

Scenes.Scene Heading: CUT TO: INT. LOBBY - NIGHT
Scenes.Description: Josh comes out of the lecture hall into the lobby, where students are standing around. He dials his cell phone.

Dialogues.Line: You're great.
Thanks.

Scenes.Scene Heading: CUT TO: EXT. CONNECTICUT HIGHWAY - NIGHT
Scenes.Description: Toby and Sam are still in the car. Toby's phone rings. He answers it.

Dialogues.Line: Yeah.
What's going on?
Sam feels we're zeroing in on it.
You haven't found it yet?
We've been navigating by the North Star, which turned out to be the Delta shuttle from LaGuardia. It's a miracle we're not in Nantucket right now. [glares at Sam]
Toby, how hard can it be to find the Wesley police station?
I don't know, Josh, but while we're looking, can you tell me a little more about the President's secret plan to fight inflation?
How long until you let up on me on that?
Oh, it's gonna take a little while I would think.
Call me when you know something. [hangs up]
There's a store open up there. I'm gonna pull over and ask 'em if they know where the Wesley police station is.
Or you could just pull in there, [points] at the Wesley police station and ask them.
Hey!
Yeah.
Look!
Yeah.
We found it!
Let's get this done and get outta here. They pull into the parking lot at the police station. They get out of the car.

Scenes.Scene Heading: FADE IN: INT. WESLEY POLICE STATION - NIGHT
Scenes.Description: Sam goes up to the desk, where OFFICER PETER is reading the newspaper. Toby hangs back and paces.

Dialogues.Line: Good evening.
Evening.
[shows I.D.] My name is Sam Seaborn. I work for the President of the United States. Is your watch commander around?
Is this a joke?
No.
You walk in here. You tell me you work for the President.

[looks at officer's name tag] Officer Peter, we're in a certain amount of trouble tonight and the only thing I've got going for me is that you're in more trouble than we are. My name is Sam Seaborn, I work for the President and the sooner you reach the conclusion that I'm telling you the truth the better off we're all gonna be. Why don't you go get your watch commander? Officer Peter goes out of the room. Sam turns to Toby.
Let me tell you something. If we'd stayed on the Merritt parkway instead of getting of at exit 29 and going east to Greenwich, I don't think we'd wound up in Bridgeport so many times.
Shut up. Officer Peter comes back with SERGEANT McNAMARA. SERGEANT McNAMARA I'm Sergeant McNamara. Can I help you folks?
Sergeant, I'm Sam Seaborn. I'm the Deputy White House Communications Director. That's my boss, Toby Ziegler. [gestures to Toby] SERGEANT McNAMARA I'm not really in the mood for a joke right now.
I know how you feel. You have Roberto Mendoza locked up back there. SERGEANT McNAMARA Sir, please state your business here, or I'm gonna have to ask you to leave.
My business is to tell you to unlock the cell and give me Mendoza. Officer Peter looks down at the newspaper in the table and tried to interrupt.
Sergeant? SERGEANT McNAMARA You come in here at ten o'clock at night, and you tell me you're with the White House, and I'm just supposed to...

Sergeant! Officer Peter shows the sergeant the newspaper. On the front page is a picture of President Bartlet with Toby. The caption reads 'President Bartlet Drafts Letter to Senate Leaders.' They look up at Toby, who just smiles.
Sergeant, you've arrested a federal judge who's the President's nominee for the U.S. Supreme Court. The police phone rings.
You should get that. That's gonna be the Governor of Connecticut.

Scenes.Scene Heading: CUT TO: INT. LECTURE HALL - NIGHT
Scenes.Description: The lecture break is over, and Josh is talking again.

Dialogues.Line: Danny Concannon had thrown me a knuckle ball in the dirt, which I'd taken a big swing at and - just like that - the President had a secret plan to fight inflation.

Scenes.Scene Heading: CUT TO: INT. THE BRIEFING ROOM - PREVIOUS AFTERNOON
Scenes.Description: Josh is still behind the podium, answering questions.

Dialogues.Line: Josh, when will the President unveil his secret plan?
There is no secret plan!
You said...
[laughs] I was talking to Danny. I was kidding!
These are people's jobs we're talking about, Josh. You wanna give us a straight answer?
[looks flustered] I honestly can't remember the question.

Scenes.Scene Heading: CUT TO: INT. C.J.'S OFFICE - CONTINUOUS
Scenes.Description: C.J. groans and takes some painkillers.

Dialogues.Line: Given the reduction in unemployment, does the President have a plan to fight the ensuing inflation?

Scenes.Scene Heading: CUT TO: INT. THE BRIEFING ROOM - CONTINUOUS

Dialogues.Line: And if so, why is he keeping it a secret? Josh looks befuddled as Danny smiles triumphantly.

Scenes.Scene Heading: CUT TO: INT. HALLWAY - PREVIOUS AFTERNOON
Scenes.Description: Josh leaves the Briefing Room. Carol is standing at the door and gives him a dirty look, while Donna rushes up to him. They head for his office.

Dialogues.Line: Oh my God, Josh. I mean, oh my God!
I can fix this.
How?
I can fix this.
I don't think you can.
[yells] This'd be a great time to feel a little support from you, Donna!
You have my support, Josh.
Do I?
Yes.
Okay, good, that's a start. Tell me what you think I should do right now.
Go into your office and come up with a secret plan to fight inflation.
[yells] That's support?! They come around the corner to see C.J. standing in the door of JOSH'S OFFICE.
[yells] Joshua!
Yeah, that's the face I wanted to see right now.
What the heww happened in thewe?
You compwetewy impwoded!
What'd I do?
[translates] You completely imploded.
I wouldn't say completely.
You wewe vague, you wewe howstiwe, you wewe bewwigewant! Josh looks confused.
[translates] Belligerent.
You know what it's gonna take fow me to fix this?
I'm gonna fix this.
No, you'we not. You awe not evew awwowed in my pwess woom again!
Donna, call up Toby's office and see if he was watching. As Donna leaves, they hear Toby yelling from the hall.
[yells] Where the hell is he?
Never mind. [to C.J.] Support me on this.
No.
Thanks. [Toby walks in.] Toby...
Have you fallen on your head?
Listen...
Have you fallen down and hit your head on something hard?
I feel really bad about this.
You do?
Yes.
[sarcastic] Oh, well then I guess that's all that really matters.
Hey!
That was some very good television, Josh, and I think four network news directors will bear me out on that tonight.
I really think this isn't as bad as you're making it out to be.
A secwet pwan to fight infwation!
Okay, C.J., for a little while you're gonna have to write it down.
[bursts in] We have a problem.
No kidding!
Not Josh.
Praise God.
Although I've gotta say, telling a reporter his question's stupid's not like a page out of Dale Carnegie or anything.
Thank you.
What's the problem?
You're not gonna like it.
Believe me, Sam, the only thing that could make my day worse is if Roberto Mendoza got involved. Sam just looks at Toby, who rolls his eyes and rubs his head.

Scenes.Scene Heading: CUT TO: INT. LECTURE HALL - PRESENT

Dialogues.Line: Roberto Mendoza is the President's nominee to fill Crouch's seat on the Supreme Court. The President put Toby Ziegler in charge of his confirmation, which is a huge responsibility. A failed confirmation for the Court is a body blow to a presidency. Besides which, he's a brilliant jurist and we badly want him on the bench. The confirmation process is a tough needle to thread. You gotta make a lot of friends and Supreme Court nominees don't speak before their confirmation, they let the White House speak for them. Something Toby's had a little bit of trouble teaching Roberto Mendoza.

Scenes.Scene Heading: CUT TO: INT. ROOSEVELT ROOM - PREVIOUS AFTERNOON
Scenes.Description: C.J., Toby, Sam and Josh are waiting. Leo walks in.

Dialogues.Line: He said the President was wrong?
He said the Pwesident was wong to make Secwetawy O'Weawy apowogize-
What the hell is...?
C.J. Sam, tell him.
He said the President was wrong to make Secretary O'Leary apologize.
To who?
To Wooden.
I'm saying, to whom did he say it to?
Chicago Tribune.
I thought he's on vacation?
He is.
I thought he's on vacation in Nova Scotia?
He is.
What, they called him in Nova Scotia?
Yeah.
How the hell did they find him in Nova Scotia?
They have telephones in Nova Scotia, Leo. It's not Amish country.
[glares at Josh] I really think of all the people in this building, Josh, you want to be the last person to speak right now.
You bet.
The Pwesident needs to be bwiefed on the events of the day.
C.J., so help me if you use the words 'Pwesident' or 'bwiefed' again.

All right. The President lands in New Orleans in an hour and a half. There'll be no press at the Labor Conference. And when he's done he's getting right back on the plane and coming home. Wheels down is 3:00 a.m. He'll be back in the residence by 3:30. [starts to leave]
Can I say something?
[annoyed, stops and turns back] What?!
A lot of this is our fault. And the President probably isn't going to take this very well and we just want you to know that we will be there with you in spirit tomorrow morning.
You're gonna be there with me in every way imaginable, Josh.
You bet.
[to all] 7:00 a.m. [leaves]

Scenes.Scene Heading: CUT TO: INT. LECTURE HALL - PRESENT

Dialogues.Line: If you read the papers, you know that this not the first time this had happened. In the eight weeks since the President named his nominee, Judge Mendoza has, on various occasions, publicly criticized the American Bar Association, the AFL-CIO, and the New York state legislature. Three organizations without which this President would not have been elected. Putting out the Deborah O'Leary fire from earlier in the day had been the only thing we'd been successful at, and now Judge Mendoza had... Josh's phone rings again.
...started it up again. I-I... I'm really very sorry, but I have to get this. [gets up and answers the phone] Yeah.
Josh.
Yeah.

Scenes.Scene Heading: CUT TO: INT. WESLEY POLICE STATION - NIGHT
Scenes.Description: Sam updates Josh on what happened.

Dialogues.Line: We're in.
Where is he?
Toby's talking to him now.

Scenes.Scene Heading: CUT TO: INT. WESLEY POLICE CELL - NIGHT
Scenes.Description: Officer Peter is letting Toby into the cell where Judge Mendoza is lying on a cot.

Dialogues.Line: Hello Mr. Justice. How are you?
Incarcerated, Toby. How're you?
Do you need anything, Mr. Ziegler?
No. Judge and I are gonna have a chat. [goes into the cell]

Scenes.Scene Heading: FADE IN: INT. LECTURE HALL - NIGHT

Dialogues.Line: The hardest job in the White House is President. The second hardest job is not Chief of Staff, it's not National Security Advisor, and it's not Press Secretary, although I'm gaining a certain amount of respect for Press Secretaries. The second hardest job in the White House belongs to a 21 year old kid named Charlie Young. He's what's called the President's body man, his personal aide. He's with the President morning to night. He has a range of responsibilities, all of them difficult. But the one he hates most in this from time to time it is his job to wake the President up in the morning. And on this particular morning, the President had gone to sleep only three hours earlier.

Scenes.Scene Heading: CUT TO: INT. OUTER OVAL OFFICE - DAY
Scenes.Description: Early that morning, Charlie is talking on the phone. The operator, Helen, answers.

Dialogues.Line: Good morning, White House operator four. How may I direct your call?
Good morning, Helen. It's Charlie.
Hey babe. How was New Orleans?
The President did very well.
Have you been to sleep yet?
Since when?
Since yesterday.
[laughs] Good one, Helen. It's time for the President's wake up call.
Lucky you. Let me put you through.

Scenes.Scene Heading: CUT TO: INT. THE PRESIDENT'S BEDROOM - CONTINUOUS
Scenes.Description: Bartlet is asleep in his bedroom. The phone rings four times before he finally answers it sleepily.

Dialogues.Line: What?
Good morning, Mr. President. It's Charlie. I hope...
What could you possibly want right now?
Sir, it's 6:30 a.m. and...
In the morning?
Yes sir. And I wanted to remind you that...
I mean, what in the name of everything holy could you want right now?

I wanted to remind you that you have a 7:00 a.m. at the Oval Office with senior staff, followed by your security and intelligence briefings, and a meeting with the Chairman of the Fed. Would you like me to have the stewards bring you some coffee and the Washington Post?
Who the hell is this?
Sir.
And what could you possibly want?
Sir. I need you to dig in now. It wasn't a nightmare. You really are the President.
All right.
I'll have the stewards bring the coffee to your room.
I'll get up now. [hangs up the phone with difficulty]

Scenes.Scene Heading: CUT TO: INT. LECTURE HALL - PRESENT

Dialogues.Line: Mendoza was summoned to the White House from his vacation in Nova Scotia. When you summon someone to the White House, you generally expect to see them within the hour. Judge Mendoza told us that he would see us in three days. Why three days? Because he was driving down to D.C., stopping in Connecticut to do some antiquing. Yet another thing we'd have to tell the President. Who, by the way, had still not woken up.

Scenes.Scene Heading: CUT TO: INT. RESIDENCE HALLWAY - DAY
Scenes.Description: Early that morning, Charlie comes around the corner to find BILLY, the steward, waiting outside the bedroom door.

Dialogues.Line: Charlie.
Oh, come on.
I've been knocking every few minutes or so, and I don't hear the shower running either.
Thanks, Billy. Give me a minute, would you?
You bet.

Scenes.Scene Heading: CUT TO: INT. THE PRESIDENT'S BEDROOM - CONTINUOUS
Scenes.Description: Charlie goes into the bedroom and turns on a few lamps. He tries to wake up Bartlet.

Dialogues.Line: Mr. President... Mr. President. [shakes the President] Mr. President...
[wakes up and quickly grabs Charlie's wrist] Charlie, are you aware you're committing a federal crime right now?
I'll take my chances with the Feds, Mr. President. It's seven o'clock.
How did you know the First Lady wasn't going to be naked when you came in here? [looks at her empty side of the bed] Come to think of it, where the hell is my wife?
Argentina.
That's right.
Senior staff at the Oval Office, sir. So I'm gonna stand here while you get outta bed, take a shower and get dressed. [holds up the President's robe]
[finally gets up] Have you slept yet?
No sir.
Good. Charlie helps the President put on his robe.

Scenes.Scene Heading: CUT TO: INT. OUTER OVAL OFFICE - DAY
Scenes.Description: The senior staff are waiting inside.

Dialogues.Line: [to C.J.] How's your mouth?
Well, the swelling's gone down. On the other hand, the painkillers have worn off.
He's driving from Nova Scotia to Washington?
Yeah.
How's a person do that?

Oh, my guess is, he'll take the Trans-Canada Highway to New Brunswick, then maybe catch the 1 and take the scenic route along the coast of Maine. 95 through New Hampshire to the Mass Pike, and then cut over to the Merritt Parkway round Milford. They all look at Sam like he's crazy. Toby vocalizes it.
Something really kinda freakish about you, you know that? Bartlet comes in from the Mural Room.

I'm tired, I'm cranky, and my wife's in Argentina. Let's get this over with. They all follow him into THE OVAL OFFICE, where Bartlet stands in front of his desk and they form a semi-circle around him.
What?
Mr. President, we experienced a few public relations, what's the word...?
Catastrophes?
...incidents in the few hours you were away last night.
What kind of incidents? Everyone looks at Josh, who is looking at his feet.
Josh.

Yeah? [gets it] Oh. First, I'm happy to tell you that the incident involving Secretary O'Leary and Congressman Wooden has been dispensed with. Though not really, and I'll get to that at the end. Sam asked C.J. to move the briefing to two o'clock so that we could fold in the teachers. C.J. had emergency root canal surgery at noon and so was unable to brief.
Who did?
I did.
Oh God.
Yeah. A long story short, you're gonna be reading a bit today about your secret plan to fight inflation.
I have a secret plan to fight inflation?
No.
Why am I gonna be reading that I do?
It was suggested in the Press Room that you did.
By who?
By me.
You told the press I have a secret plan to fight inflation?
No, I did not. Let me be absolutely clear, I did not do that. Except, yes, I did that.
Josh, I'm a little confused.
Sir, there was this idiotic round robin. It was sarcastic. There's no way they didn't know that. They were just mad at me for imposing discipline and calling them stupid!
Okay, before we go on. C.J., if blood is gushing from the head wound you just received from a stampeding herd of bison, you'll do the press briefing.
Yes sir.
Mr. President...
A secret plan to fight inflation?
There was no turning them back. I denied it for half an hour. They wouldn't take no for an answer.
Were you clear?
I was crystal clear. They said, 'Do you think if the President has a plan to fight inflation, it's right that be keep it a secret?' I said, 'Of course not!'
Are you telling me that not only did you invent a secret plan to fight inflation, but now you don't support it?
[looks stunned] When you put it like that...
Mr. President, much as we'd love nothing more than to stand here and watch you beat the living crap outta Josh, there's actually a bigger fish to fry.
What did Mendoza do?
He told the Chicago Tribune that you were wrong to admonish Secretary O'Leary and make her apologize.
I didn't, he did. [points at Leo]
You told me to.
You said you were gonna fix it.
I did fix it.
It's broken again, Leo.
Frankly sir, that's 'cause your nominee for the Supreme Court's handling himself in a manner that's totally unprofessional.
We will have the first of what I think will a series of discussions about professionalism another time, Toby. Where is Mendoza?
He's on his way, sir.
Right now?
Yes, but he won't be here until the day after tomorrow.
Day after tomorrow?
Yes sir.
Is he coming in from Neptune?

He's vacationing with his wife and son, and they'd prefer to take a leisurely drive through eastern Canada and New England while stopping for some antique shopping in Connecticut. I imagine he'll take the Trans-Canada Highway, the 95...
Sam.
Okay. We will wait for Mendoza. In the meantime, C.J., you will untangle the Press Corps.
Yes sir.
And we will hope that nothing happens today to make this any worse. Although I certainly wouldn't bet the house on it. That is all.
Thank you, Mr. President. They all leave, except for Josh, who hangs back as Bartlet sits at his desk.
Sir, I wanna tell you that I'm sorry and that this mess will be cleaned up in an adult and professional manner.
Good.
[quietly] If anyone asks you, you quit smoking years ago, and the cigarette you bummed on Air Force One was for a friend.
Get out.
You bet.

Scenes.Scene Heading: CUT TO: INT. LECTURE HALL - PRESENT

Dialogues.Line: And that was it.
What happened to Judge Mendoza?
I'm sorry?
Did he ever get here from Nova Scotia?
Actually, he's on his way right now. He's spending the night in Connecticut to do some antiquing.

Scenes.Scene Heading: CUT TO: INT. WESLEY POLICE STATION - NIGHT
Scenes.Description: Sam just got coffee from a vending machine and is drinking. SERGEANT McNAMARA [nervously] He's been in there a little while now.

Dialogues.Line: Yeah. SERGEANT McNAMARA I'm the one that pulled him over, you know. His driving was erratic. Still not entirely convinced he hadn't been drinking.
Well, you have a problem there. SERGEANT McNAMARA What's that?

Judge Mendoza has chronic persistent hepatitis, which is a non-progressive form of liver inflammation. If he'd had enough to drink to blow point one on the blood-alcohol, he'd be dead right now. [drinks] This is good coffee.

Scenes.Scene Heading: CUT TO: INT. WESLEY POLICE CELL - NIGHT
Scenes.Description: Toby is still having a word with Judge Mendoza.

Dialogues.Line: Why didn't you take a Breathalyzer?

Because I was driving within the speed limit, I was driving on the right side of the road, I had valid tags and registration and as far as I know, I don't have any warrants for my arrest in Connecticut.
Judge...
Absent just cause, Toby. The Breathalyzer's an illegal search. It's a civil rights violation.
So you give Barney Fife a hard time to make a point.
Point worth making.
Not now.
Yes now, right now.
One phone call, Judge. 'Toby, this has happened. Tell 'em my name's Roberto Mendoza and the President's named me to the bench!'
They pulled me over because I look like my name is Roberto Mendoza and I'm coming to rob your house.
Let's go. [starts to leave]
Where are we going?
Home. Let's go home!
I'm not going anywhere.
Judge.
I'm under arrest, Toby.
Not anymore. Let's go.
You pull all the strings you want, Toby, but not for me. Come Monday, I'm gonna inveigle myself of the criminal justice system for which I have worked my entire adult life.
Judge, due respect. Get your things and let's go.
[angrily] My kid was in the car, Toby. They patted me down and they handcuffed me in front of my nine year old boy. Then he and his mother got to see them put me in the squad car and drive away.
He's also seen you wearing a robe with a gavel in your hand.

He doesn't understand that. He doesn't know what that is. He understands what the police are because he watches television. That's what he's gonna remember, his father being handcuffed. So America just got another pissed-off guy with dark skin.
Robbie and Laura, where are they right now?
Motel a few miles...

There's nothing about this that doesn't stink. If it were me, I'd wanna extract vengeance, and I'd say 'Let justice be done.' I'd also wanna spend some time in a dark room alone, so that I didn't have to face my wife and my son and have them see my humiliation. Rob, I can't get this done if this is the story. Can't get it done. Nothing about this that doesn't stink. And nothing about it that wouldn't be better if you were a Supreme Court Justice. Let me take you to the motel. Go see your boy.

Scenes.Scene Heading: CUT TO: INT. WESLEY POLICE STATION - NIGHT
Scenes.Description: In the lobby, Sam is playing with his coffee cup.

Dialogues.Line: So, can I ask, a guy in your job, do you know missile codes and that sort of thing?
Yeah.
Outstanding. Toby and Mendoza come out of the back room.
Good evening, Mr. Justice.
Good evening, Sam.
[to Officer Peter] You got personal items?
Yes sir. He leaves to get Mendoza's stuff.

Your lucky night, officers. There isn't gonna be a report, there isn't going to be an investigation, no one's getting suspended. And no one's filing a hundred million dollar lawsuit against the county that they would almost surely win. But in this room, you're gonna apologize to Mr. Mendoza. And then you're gonna get in your squad car and you're gonna follow us and you're gonna apologize to his son. SERGEANT McNAMARA Judge Mendoza, we sincerely apologize for our mistake.
Thank you.
Let's go. Toby and Mendoza start to leave.
I also gotta say, you guys could do a better job of marking the exits on the throughway.
Let's go!
We'll be behind you.

Scenes.Scene Heading: CUT TO: EXT. WESLEY POLICE STATION - CONTINUOUS
Scenes.Description: Sam, Toby and Mendoza are walking out of the police station, heading for their car.

Dialogues.Line: You know what, Toby. If there's no reason for you guys to go back to Washington, you should spend the night here.
[opens car door] What's up here?
Great antiquing. [enters car]
Killing me, Judge. You're absolutely killing me. Toby closes the car door. Sam dials his phone.
Josh.
Yeah.
It's over.

Scenes.Scene Heading: CUT TO: INT. LECTURE HALL - NIGHT
Scenes.Description: Josh is standing to the back of the stage.

Dialogues.Line: Good. [hangs up phone and sits back down] That's the last time the phone will ring. I promise.
Josh...

There's a part of the story I didn't tell you. I can't. Trust me, it doesn't involve... I-I-I just can't right now. Ask me back again after the Senate confirms Mendoza. You really should hear it, it's a good story.
Why don't we take some questions.
Yeah. Josh turns to his audience.

Scenes.Scene Heading: DISSOLVE TO: END TITLES.
